articles.headline: Bathroom Law Repeal Leaves Few Pleased in North Carolina
articles.snippet: A compromise seeks to minimize economic damage from a law that led to boycotts, demonstrations and economic fallout from businesses, sports groups and others.
articles.abstract: A compromise seeks to minimize economic damage from a law that led to boycotts, demonstrations and economic fallout from businesses, sports groups and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For a year, it prompted boycotts, demonstrations and economic fallout that helped dethrone a sitting governor. In the end, in a strange and profoundly American collision of polarized politics, big-time sports, commerce and the culture wars, North Carolina’s notorious House Bill 2 was finally laid to rest on Thursday — though many were left wondering if some of its negative effects might linger.

articles.headline: 2 White House Officials Helped Give Nunes Intelligence Reports
articles.snippet: The revelation fueled criticism that Representative Devin Nunes has been too eager to do the White House’s bidding, not run an independent investigation
articles.abstract: The revelation fueled criticism that Representative Devin Nunes has been too eager to do the White House’s bidding, not run an independent investigation
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A pair of White House officials helped provide Representative Devin Nunes of California, a Republican and the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, with the intelligence reports that showed that President Trump and his associates were incidentally swept up in foreign surveillance by American spy agencies.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Maggie Haberman and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Sears and Its Hedge Fund Owner, in Slow Decline Together
articles.snippet: Edward Lampert was a Wall Street wunderkind. And department stores still had promise. What a difference a decade makes.
articles.abstract: Edward Lampert was a Wall Street wunderkind. And department stores still had promise. What a difference a decade makes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge funds have been failing over the last year at the fastest rate since the financial crisis in 2008. Some crashed and burned after sudden reversals. Others quietly liquidated.

articles.headline: Venezuela Muzzles Legislature, Moving Closer to One-Man Rule
articles.snippet: A ruling by the country’s Supreme Court appears to allow the court, which is controlled by loyalists to the president, to write laws itself, experts say.
articles.abstract: A ruling by the country’s Supreme Court appears to allow the court, which is controlled by loyalists to the president, to write laws itself, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: IQUITOS, Peru — Venezuela took its strongest step yet toward one-man rule under the leftist President Nicolás Maduro as his loyalists on the Supreme Court seized power from the National Assembly in a ruling late Wednesday night.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Patricia Torres

articles.headline: Senate Narrowly Passes Rollback of Obama-Era ‘Auto-I.R.A.’ Rule
articles.snippet: The vote to kill a regulation allowing cities and counties to set up retirement savings accounts for some workers was a startling reversal for many Republicans.
articles.abstract: The vote to kill a regulation allowing cities and counties to set up retirement savings accounts for some workers was a startling reversal for many Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By a single vote, the Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a measure to block cities and counties from organizing retirement savings accounts for workers who have no access to employer-sponsored plans. The vote reverses a Labor Department rule that allows local governments to automatically enroll private-sector workers in retirement plans unless they opt out.

articles.headline: Student Loan Forgiveness Program Approval Letters May Be Invalid, Education Dept. Says
articles.snippet: Over 550,000 people have applied to have their student loans forgiven, and thousands of approval letters have been sent. But they might be wrong.
articles.abstract: Over 550,000 people have applied to have their student loans forgiven, and thousands of approval letters have been sent. But they might be wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 550,000 people have signed up for a federal program that promises to repay their remaining student loans after they work 10 years in a public service job.

articles.headline: Also Made in Mexico: Lifesaving Medical Devices
articles.snippet: The medical supply industry makes a particularly revelatory case study of the difficulties of untangling global trade.
articles.abstract: The medical supply industry makes a particularly revelatory case study of the difficulties of untangling global trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — The North American Free Trade Agreement has transformed this sprawling border town from gritty party spot to something entirely different: a world capital of medical devices.
